DataElement.preferredName: Formalin Fixed Paraffin Embedded Tissue Block Storage Follow Standard Operating Procedure Indicator
DataElement.preferredDefinition: An indication of whether the specimen was collected and stored in accordance with the specified SOP.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Formalin Fixed Paraffin Embedded Tissue Block Storage Follow Standard Operating Procedure
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A colorless poisonous gas synthesized by the oxidation of methanol and used as an antiseptic, disinfectant, histologic fixative, and general-purpose chemical reagent for laboratory applications.  Formaldehyde is readily soluble in water and is commonly distributed as a 37% solution in water; formalin, a 10% solution of formaldehyde in water, is used as a disinfectant and to preserve biological specimens. Environmentally, formaldehyde may be found in the atmosphere, smoke from fires, automobile exhaust and cigarette smoke.  Small amounts are produced during normal metabolic processes in most organisms, including humans. (NCI04)_Tissue which is preserved in a fixative solution, usually formalin._Tissue that is preserved and embedded in paraffin._The act or process of making something ready._Refers to preserved specimens embedded in support material. These are typically cut into thin slices for microscopic examination, with or without an enhancement such as staining._The act of safekeeping goods in a depository._Adhere to or practice._An established procedure to be followed in carrying out a given operation or in a given situation.

ObjectClass.preferredName: Formaldehyde Fixed Specimen Paraffin Embedded Tissue Preparation
ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A colorless poisonous gas synthesized by the oxidation of methanol and used as an antiseptic, disinfectant, histologic fixative, and general-purpose chemical reagent for laboratory applications. Formaldehyde is readily soluble in water and is commonly distributed as a 37% solution in water; formalin, a 10% solution of formaldehyde in water, is used as a disinfectant and to preserve biological specimens. Environmentally, formaldehyde may be found in the atmosphere, smoke from fires, automobile exhaust and cigarette smoke. Small amounts are produced during normal metabolic processes in most organisms, including humans.:Tissue which is preserved in a fixative solution, usually formalin.:Tissue that is preserved and embedded in paraffin.:The act or process of making something ready.

Concepts.definition: A colorless poisonous gas synthesized by the oxidation of methanol and used as an antiseptic, disinfectant, histologic fixative, and general-purpose chemical reagent for laboratory applications. Formaldehyde is readily soluble in water and is commonly distributed as a 37% solution in water; formalin, a 10% solution of formaldehyde in water, is used as a disinfectant and to preserve biological specimens. Environmentally, formaldehyde may be found in the atmosphere, smoke from fires, automobile exhaust and cigarette smoke. Small amounts are produced during normal metabolic processes in most organisms, including humans.
Tissue which is preserved in a fixative solution, usually formalin.
Tissue that is preserved and embedded in paraffin.
The act or process of making something ready.

Property.preferredName: Block Storage Follow Standard Operating Procedure
Property.preferredDefinition: Refers to preserved specimens embedded in support material.  These are typically cut into thin slices for microscopic examination, with or without an enhancement such as staining.:The act of safekeeping goods in a depository.:Adhere to or practice.:An established procedure to be followed in carrying out a given operation or in a given situation.

Concepts.definition: Refers to preserved specimens embedded in support material.  These are typically cut into thin slices for microscopic examination, with or without an enhancement such as staining.
The act of safekeeping goods in a depository.
An established procedure to be followed in carrying out a given operation or in a given situation.
